answers.author: Ghida Neukirch
answers.text:
In Buffalo Grove, Illinois, we have rolled out iPads to all elected officials and eliminated all paper board meeting packets, with the exception of an original for the Clerk's office.   I'm happy to talk to you if you are considering a roll out.  We implemented E-packets 10 yrs ago and the pilot crashed and failed due to limited technology.  It's 100% better this time.

answers.author: Scott Trainor
answers.text:
We've been looking into the same issue and have found that Boulder, Fort Collins, and Broomfield, CO all have small pilot programs that they're running with a few Council-members.  The Town of Center, CO is using iPad 2's for their paperless Council meetings.  Those communities may have some experiences to share with you.

answers.author: Greg Balukonis
answers.text:
North Reading, MA has used IPads for it's Board meetings since January.  We are totally paperless and the elected Board members are very pleased.  The town uses DropBox to deposit meeting packages, correspondence, reports, etc that are of interest to elected officials who are then responsible for retrieving them at their leisure.

author: Ryan Waller
text:
Lake County is researching the feasibility of introducing iPads to the IT network and providing to various Staff and Elected officials.  Have other communities successfully implemented such technology and corresponding policies to govern use?  
Thank you.
